0.user_question: The ice cream parlor was offering a deal, buy 2 scoops of ice cream, get 1 scoop free.  Each scoop cost $1.50.  If Erin had  $9810512, how many scoops of ice cream should she buy?

1.subquestion: How many sets (each set includes one paid and two freebies) could be bought from $9810512 if every third scoop costs nothing extra?

subanswer.text: Firstly we need to find out how many individual scoops can be purchased using $9810512 when buying only full price ($1.50). We divide this amount by the cost per single scoop which equates to $9810512 / $1.50/scoop = 6540341 scoops purchasable without any deals applied. As part of the special offer you pay for two but receive three, so effectively your unit rate becomes $(2*$1.5)/(3*scoops)=$1/scoop within these offers. Since buying pairs results into getting another pair “free”, if we want just consider purchased quantity without counting those who come gratis,we take half of obtained result — $$\frac{3270170}{2}=\boxed{1635085}$$ Thus,Erin needs to buy $1635085 \times 2=\boxed{3270170}$scoops(pairs). Condition 2: One regular price scoop costs $1.50.  Condition 3: Erin has $9810512 available to spend on ice cream. Question: Based on the special offer, how many individual scoops of ice cream could Erin afford to buy using her entire budget?

ost_step.2: With $9810512 as the amount she wants to use up entirely, we divide it into pairs first; hence divided by triplets since each trio contains only paying portion which amounts to $3/scoop=triplet worth $.

Let’s calculate :$\frac{9810512}{\frac{(1.\overline{.5})}{(.5)}}$.
